# **Collective Kindness — Q1 Board Update**

Dear Board Members,

Thank you for taking the time to stay connected with the growth and evolution of Collective Kindness. Your time and presence truly means a lot.

We are thrilled to welcome our newest board member, Mimi Askanarim, who brings both deep expertise and a tremendous heart to our mission\! 

Mimi played a huge role in helping us earlier. And now that she’s joined our Board of Directors, she has already rolled up her sleeves, stepping into a complex case involving a single mother and providing invaluable assessment and support. We are truly blessed to have her on board.

**Note**:   
*We didn’t come to a consensus for time to meet. I’ve added new times for us to vote on. [Please take 30 seconds](https://doodle.com/group-poll/participate/eXpnlYke) and share some availability. Thanks\!*

## **Mission Alignment Check-in**

Our mission remains clear: to implement smart chessed — helping families in crisis, with whom we see a clear path to future financial stability.

We remain deeply committed to working in an organized and strategic manner while preserving the nimbleness that has defined our roots. A recent example of this commitment occurred even as we prepared this update: a mother of twelve reached out, desperate to prevent her child from losing a spot at the camp of their choice due to unpaid fees. Our team immediately paused their work, spoke directly with the camp director, secured a temporary hold on the matter, and had already raised half of the needed funds within hours. This responsiveness is a core strength we are proud to maintain.

## **Key Achievements**

We made significant progress in both fundraising and service delivery during Q1.

On the fundraising and donor outreach side, we engaged with several major institutions and individuals. We held meetings with UJA, the Paul Singer Foundation, Dan Loeb’s Foundation, the Crain-Maling Foundation, Jay Schottenstein, and many more. Some didn’t end up as obvious successes, but like George Rohr told us, “just keep swinging. You’ll get hits.”

We have a meeting to get advice from philanthropist David Magerman and are strategizing outreach efforts for the Walder Foundation. We also engaged with the Mayberg Foundation and the Rose Community Foundation. Although Rose ultimately declined support, we received useful feedback on differentiating our services. A major highlight this quarter was securing a new recurring donor committing $10,000 per month and several additional donors “Adopted families”

If you have any ideas of people or foundations that we can reach out to, please let Shalom know. We’d be super grateful.

In client services, we expanded our reach and impact:

* There are now 48 active families with ongoing services.  
  ![][image2]  
* Successful Purim and Pesach campaigns distributed **approximately** **$50,000** directly to families in need.

* Added key personnel, including:

  * One Virtual Assistant (at $3.50/hour)  
  * Two new Case Managers  
  * Two Budgeters  
  * One additional JPA  
  * Two new Debt Experts  
  * One Resume Writer

We also made important technology upgrades:

* Enhanced Airtable for greater client privacy and operational efficiency, ensuring case managers only see their assigned clients.  
  Built a Zoho CRM system to centralize and streamline donor tracking across multiple platforms and offline channels.

Finally, we expanded the **Shluchim Thrive** program. Part of George Rohr’s donation has been allocated toward its growth. We are onboarding two new Shluchim while refining the program’s focus. Rather than pursuing strict cash flow positivity as we do with families, Shluchim Thrive emphasizes achieving personal clarity and sustainable success in their shlichus. Services include mentorship, debt management, therapy support, budgeting assistance, and potential virtual assistant and fundraising coaching.

## **Challenges**

While we made meaningful progress, we continue to face significant challenges.

* First and foremost, we urgently need to build steady monthly revenue to create a sustainable operating base. Our goal is to reach $50,000 per month in recurring donations, allowing us to operate on a reliable budget and plan proactively. **Currently we average $38,130** (not including outliers) in recurring revenue each month.  
* We also recognize the need to hire a Director of Operations who can oversee internal management and free up leadership capacity. In addition, we are aware that a long-term replacement for our Client Coordinator role must be recruited to ensure we have strong, skilled leadership across all departments.  
* Another pressing challenge is improving the client journey between Phase 1 (immediate financial crisis management) and Phase 2 (sustainability, career support, and therapy). We are working to design clearer pathways and transitions for the families we serve.  
  * If anyone would like to learn the process better and help us strategize ways of fixing this hole in our system, we’d be appreciative

## **Q1 Financial Snapshot**

Please find attached the [Q1 Financial Snapshot](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/110GjmYOz1tzZ3UFKNjw3uuiYXEpTh1ra?usp=sharing) prepared by our Accountant and CFO, Shaul Wasserman.

Please note that the CEO's compensation appears higher in March. We followed up with Shaul, and he clarified that this was due to the CEO (Shalom) receiving payment at the end of the month (March 30th/31st), resulting in a slight overlap. Moving forward, we will ensure CEO compensation is issued at the beginning of each month to avoid any confusion.

## **Looking Ahead**

Looking toward the next quarter, we are focused on several priorities. 

* We aim to grow from 48 to 65 active families receiving support.   
* We are seeking opportunities to secure positive media coverage, particularly targeting a feature in EJewishPhilanthropy, and we welcome suggestions for additional media outlets that could highlight our work. We were featured on [Hamodia](https://mail-attachment.googleusercontent.com/attachment/u/0/?ui=2&ik=addb15386b&attid=0.1&permmsgid=msg-a:r824857667555975187&th=1965a9be81a76b69&view=att&disp=inline&realattid=1D4FB222-CD59-4EE2-89CC-A3A7658DE74E&zw&saddbat=ANGjdJ8pZKZvLdVy5rQNeAZhaf3UoluqKjmFmLl0xI8E2u8BDTFJ6qhUI52F6zg6WmA5rrjeT76FRR7cK8vp4gB6LHiMcz0l42TjNx9Km29OGqfldObogycjs9PgSSE-aVvjww5uTibDRSb6wHtU6g8VFzsWkQj3yvHExIiu-cf_lwxU1_sjVFYMUxZ0eOKoh_piNY7FRLsrFPNwZr_4zU8K_DO2XjCpA5jjZYgexhI0ZkfVcq6dafQQIjq2g4lnenxC0E4M-rknFmcKfwsBS5-5NzELfhYV2G43JLeYAXORvmXRErd1AOk41XqCr51aPb9oXuVGbVNiVET3CU7jHaiMze3Ap606sret18234J_5Hs4Hg2McfjPAcFJGb-hLYXXnRvsQgP89kJDOWz2OqU5fCOFETH46jKaY0-Br0MqHqNh9iDa8rKE6i358DmsEnwqKYzqrPpmr_NVjfnY7-nK9kKgUVKiAGNojRxd2hrYtZbBETYe8rWPWEImqqWVJ4aKyUKN_viGC6ez_VrX4QrrPRKZp2wgAPQ1AQiteFyelquMtVkjBxtIivVGsoT8XASzjt0iJMxxuhu4oFnbulRdesEXjf4yT7Hk_gnIUOXSa8kdJBYclr5iYfaJ1Ql1RVWlQKOl0ODWf8Yvs6WW8iFPn5iw_aLvhnPE8UbSATfwYrg7lhk_Re6kRLH2O4VbgNPlDbZ0jjGZuVJN_Y-j2mRx4mo8e2YJ24y4f0umKSDiEVRCBZEHWPyP_SGFCTM2ZAh-EujiPPtDdDpjEk54PaijDawW6m5m8IM4TA3oDzYtjlgNPnJWzFC9OLQtB6SKxpIw50E7XjWxe6k-VocT9WDIxUMjkqpneFqunPfk9d6vYd-MRl5fVg5gLD_FL-hCZztfjMiIUeMVjsTCkCjd0H06wHHy6y2sbwBlKsyhCYTcvVpdHm3eXw6N1oCMVGSRdHlAwhrmFtmj91xI2IIzybJdZJ7JA8h77vNn4E3vSe5bLsKgWWaCoNBvRXmZ4pn-Xh_jp5po7CKgqiTYvwHp3mtJ8mwp40UgGeCbhnjfCYrFey7xoTMG-BwkZga1W4L52Kqqpw3YZXJPTpjL7_sJ22ztAz6onM1arKMiFEU1ejDPslWneiWK4E4SiJXvmIU9438ER82kdby1Hqz1fL8wZ).   
  * If you have any ideas or connections with media outlets and would like to introduce us, we’d be very grateful\!  
* Strengthening our steady cashflow remains a top objective, as does ensuring that Shalom finalizes a salary that works for everyone, allowing him to focus fully on leading Collective Kindness.  
* We are preparing for strategic meetings with Todd Stern, a Chicago philanthropist, and the Walder Foundation. Our goal is to present a compelling program proposal centered around supporting Jewish single mothers in the Chicago area.  
* Finally, we are considering launching a major fundraising campaign targeting $200,000. We invite board members' thoughts on whether this is an advisable move and on any other creative fundraising ideas that can help us meet our ambitious goals.

## **Closing Note**

Thank you for reading and for caring so deeply about the mission and future of Collective Kindness. As we meet and interact with more organizations, it becomes increasingly clear how unique and vital our work truly is.

We are grateful for your partnership and look forward to building the future of Collective Kindness together.

Warmly,  
Shalom Goodman  
Executive Director   
Collective Kindness
